pr_title: HttpClient module for azure-core-http based on the JDK 11+ HttpClient

timeline.message: Extremely early proof of concept JDK 11 HttpClient module for azure-core-http
Switching to response body publisher from inputstream, cleanup.

timeline.bodyText: @JonathanGiles I think this bug in JDK11 HttpClient may be a blocker for this HttpClient adoption. "Date" is a necessary header for many of the track2 libs, something we need to look into.
timeline.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: In that case we would only support this on JDK 12 and later, which is unfortunate.
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: added necessary validation to log error in case this client is ever used with java_version <= 11.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.message: Minor improvements
Further work

timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: If there are multiple values in java.net.http.HttpHeaders, instead of overwriting the value field here, we should have comma-separated values as recommended in the RFC
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: cool, updated to join multi-values using comma separator.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.bodyText: May want to log a warning here when we find a restricted header to let the user know that we skipped over some headers.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: yes, updated to log these as errors.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: How will this work for libraries which require fine tuning for these headers? In the case of Storage the upload could fail on a mismatch Content-Length header and shared key credential authentication will fail if the Date header is mismatch compared to what was used to generate the key.
timeline.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText:
If JDK httpClient supports completely disabling its header checks programmatically then that would be the easiest path. So far we didn't see that Netty/OkHttp blocking any headers.
If full disabling is not possible then we need to see if the native HTTP client has a programmatic way to white list subset of headers, if yes we can identify the headers that JDK blocks by default but required by our SDKs to function properly and white list them.
Yet to explore.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText:
Relaxed validations and added necessary log messages as agreed offline.
Regarding the headers we care about:
Date header is allowed from JDK12+
Content-Length header will be set by JDK native HttpClient before sending out the requests.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: good question :) it won't. Is our current digest auth code just pluggable? or it's tailored per HTTP client? I haven't looked into that yet.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: digest-auth is on hold for now, like we discussed this will be picked up once we hear from native HTTP client owner.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.author: alzimmermsft
alzimmermsft
alzimmermsft
alzimmermsft
alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: It's an implementation package type but added minimal Javadoc for this.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.bodyText: This should be more flexible in its configuration, if someone is using Java 12+ and set the system property to allow restricted headers we should allow these headers.
timeline.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText:
I added this initially to avoid JDK11 HttpClient native builder from throwing an exception. Thinking what would be the best approach here:
Maybe we can copy over the same jdk11+ logic around the header whitelisting here or if the exception thrown by the JDK11+ HttpClient native builder has a special error code for disallowed headers then we can catch, log and continue.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Relaxed validations and added necessary log messages as agreed offline.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.message: JDKHttpClient: Cleanup and test cases.
sync upstream

timeline.bodyText: This could be made static right?
timeline.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: could be, it uses instance-level logger, so static means we need to pass it.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: going with a private instance-level method, Can be static if we ever move this method to utils.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.message: JdkHttpClient: Overriding maven compiler release to 11 from 8

JdkHttpClient: Address spotbug and checkstyle
JdkHttpClient: rename dir from azure-core-http-jdk11-httpclient to azure-core-http-jdk-httpclient

JdkHttpClient: specifying version for compiler plugin
JdkHttpClient: Updating the README to follow the general readme template, adding connectionTimeout sample to README.
Adding javadoc for ProxyOptions::Type::toProxyType()
Fixing checkstyle in azure-core okhttp builder
JdkHttpClient: Adding jdk-httpclient to the artifact list in ci.yml (enables release task for this lib)
JdkHttpClient: Adding jdk-httpclient to core pom module list
JdkHttpClient: don't ignore header multi-values
JdkHttpClient: Adding code snippet for connectionTimeout
JdkHttpClient: Fix code snippet reference
JdkHttpClient: Override the 1.8 and 11+ profile
JdkHttpClient: Ensure README and ReadmeSamples are in sync
JdkHttpClient: fix code snippet reference name
